metadata.title: Make Your Data Models Into Websites | by Cody Nicholson | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Make Your Data Models Into Websites
metadata.description: You made it! Thanks to your analytical genius you managed to determine the leading factors for predicting real estate prices over the next ten years in your area, or the lead causes of climate…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Master The Basics Of Git & GitHub

all_paragraphs: You made it! Thanks to your analytical genius you managed to determine the leading factors for predicting real estate prices over the next ten years in your area, or the lead causes of climate change, or the words you can use in product descriptions that correlate with the highest sales on Amazon. There is only one small problem: You need to share your findings with the world!

In this article I’m going to show you how to deploy your data models as websites for free using the tools: Python, Jupyter Lab/Notebook, Git, and GitHub. Click on any of these below links to see the websites for projects I have worked on in the last few years:

Seaborn Demo Project, Lane Line Finding Project, Character Classifier Project, Vehicle Detection Project, Traffic Sign Classifier Project, Advanced Finding Lane Lines Project, Behavioral Cloning Project
PREREQUISITES: Install Python, install jupyterlab, install Git, have a GitHub account
On your GitHub account you should create a new repository, then git clone that repository to your computer.
If you have any trouble with the Git & GitHub portion of this article — see “Master The Basics Of Git & GitHub”
The commands you will use should look something like this:
You should now be looking at Jupyter Lab which should have opened a tab in your default browser

If you had problems with the git clone command: Make sure you have git installed using the link provided above. Make sure the link you provided is the HTTPS link you copied from clicking the green “clone or download” button in your GitHub repository.

If you had problems with the jupyter lab command: Make sure you installed jupyter lab correctly. I used the “pip install jupyterlab” option from the various options they provide when you follow the install link above.

In your newly opened Jupyter Lab click the “Python 3” box under the “Notebook” header. This should create a new Untitled.ipynb file and open it for you. From this new file you can write and run your Python code in code cells and add titles and descriptions in markdown cells.

In the above picture you will see that I’ve created two cells. The first cell is a Markdown Title cell where I have added the title “My Project Website” that will appear as a title because I put the “#” before the words. Running that cell will produce a nicely formatted title. Below that cell I created a code cell that simply prints “hello world”. Saving that file with whatever name you choose will conclude the creating of our Jupyter Notebook for this demo. See my project links at the beginning of this article for examples of more advanced logic you could add to your notebook in the future.
In our open Jupyter Lab tab go to: File → Export Notebook As… → Export Notebook to HTML. This will download an HTML file with the same name as your ipynb file.
Once we have this file downloaded you should move it into your repository and make sure you rename the file: index.html
In your terminal or git bash window — make sure you are in your Git repository. Then we should run this command to select all updated files in our repository to be committed:
Next, we’ll run this command to commit all of our changed files with a useful message:
Lastly we can push it up using this command:
If we go to our GitHub repository after this we should see:
Back in our GitHub repository online we’ll click the “Settings” button that is the last option in the toolbar under the “Username/Repository Name” link at the top of the page.

On the following Settings page — scroll down to the “GitHub Pages” section of the “Options” menu. You should see a “Source” header — and below that a drop-down menu with the default option “None” selected.
Select “master branch” from the drop-down menu and that will refresh your Settings page. Scrolling back down to the “GitHub Pages” section should now show you this message highlighted in blue:

This means that the site is still being setup and you need to wait about a minute. Keep refreshing the page until the blue shaded box in the “GitHub Pages” section changes again to be highlighted green like this:
Clicking the published site link should take you to your new project website! My website can be found at: https://clairvoyantcoding.github.io/Make_Your_Data_Models_Into_Websites_Project/
You can setup a website for each of your GitHub repositories just like this one by putting an index.html file in the root of your repository and enabling GitHub pages like this.

It’s amazing that GitHub offers these free websites for each project you create — but it does come with some limitations. For each project, you cannot have more pages other than your index.html page. So if you add page2.html and try and reference it from your index.html you won’t be able to get to page2.

If a file called “.DS_Store” appeared in your repository make sure you delete it. It’s created automatically and can contain file paths you would not want to share with the world by deploying it to GitHub Pages.

Another common mistake or constraint of this project website is that your main HTML file must be named “index.html” and it must be at the root of your repository — meaning it cannot referenced from inside another folder in your repository.

Lastly, try and preface every code cell in your website with a title and/or description markdown cell. It’s so nice to be able to create project websites easily and share it with the world — but your content needs to be interpretable by any of your sites visitors. Even the ones who don’t know Python. So always try and summarize what you’re doing well for the best user experience.
Thanks for reading! I’d love to hear your feedback or take any questions or problems with this tutorial, so please comment below and I’ll try my best to help.
